content:
https://github.com/rust-lang/blog.rust-lang.org/blob/master/.github/CODEOWNERS gives an error from GitHub:
Unknown owner on line 3: make sure the team @rust-lang/inside-rust-reviewers exists and has write access to the repository
And it doesn't seem that inside-rust-reviewers has the ability to approve/commit Inside Rust blog posts anymore, likely as a result of that.
Would someone mind taking a look at permissions on that repository?
Following up on this: is there a better place to raise this?

I don't think this is really an infra-team discussion; the review strategy for the blog has long needed some attention from someone who would like to own a policy more thoroughly (not necessarily someone with bandwidth to do reviews).

My personal perspective is that we do actually want a (ideally lightweight) process of approvals that isn't just core; some kind of middle balance seems like a good idea - I do think we typically gain a lot from the reviews of blog posts in terms of improving their quality and readability after 1-2 passes, which is the primary thing I want to make sure we keep. But I haven't had the time budget to explore thinking and writing down a policy, much less circulating it :)
Implementation-wise adjusting the permissions would indeed be straightforward; I don't see that as a particular blocker.
I don't feel like there's a new policy decision to be made here. We previously made the policy decision to delegate the Inside Rust blog.
Deciding to un-delegate it would be a policy change.
The group exists, it's tracked and has members.
That group just no longer has the intended permissions.
FWIW I do absolutely think we should have review on all posts, it's just a question of who is empowered to do that review.
(I don't remember precisely where this change took place, but it was an intentional policy change, hence the existence of the inside-rust-reviewers group.)

Hm. I do recall something like that. FWIW, my recollection is that the intent was to make inside Rust and the main blog distinct at the time (i.e., main blog requires core, inside Rust does not). I'm not sure that was ever actually implemented -- maybe GitHub changed their code owners syntax?

I am a little reluctant to "just" fix the permissions -- I think project group leads having direct write access to the blog (even inside Rust) feels a little like it might raise the bar for appointing a lead higher than I at least want; I think the definition and use of project groups has changed over time and so the policy such as it was may not quite apply as well today.
Anyway, it seems OK I guess to just fix the permissions (i.e., make inside rust reviewers actually able to review) and we can re-evaluate as needed
Adjusted.
To the best of my knowledge the permissions worked at some point, though I may be mistaken.
I don't think anyone should have "direct write" access; I think all access should go through PRs with review required, where for Inside Rust the folks in the inside-rust-reviewers group could review.
That was always the intention as far as I know; nobody should have direct write.
I do agree that we need to take care who is in inside-rust-reviewers. I don't think we expected that project groups would have direct permission; I would expect that governance teams would.
The current config has project group leads included (https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/teams/inside-rust-reviewers.toml#L8)

Branch protection is enabled, so a group/team would likely have to self-review -- I think there may be some value in encouraging 'not your team' to review, though it's complicated and maybe not worth it.

simulacrum said:

Branch protection is enabled, so a group/team would likely have to self-review -- I think there may be some value in encouraging 'not your team' to review, though it's complicated and maybe not worth it.

I think it's appropriate for a member of the same team to review a post, as long as it's not the same person.

simulacrum said:

The current config has project group leads included (https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/teams/inside-rust-reviewers.toml#L8)

I've seen a few conversations about changing that. It seems reasonable to get whatever team a project group reports up through to approve a post.
I think it depends on the post
For some posts ease of publishing definitely wins out to me, but it can be helpful to get reviews beyond your own small group (particularly with an eye towards "what assumptions did I make")
